mods.abstract: Subjects of particular note in this journal include Burroughs' visit with Walt Whitman on the New Jersey shore at Ocean Grove; as well as his thoughts about the writings of Charles Darwin, Thomas Carlyle, and Ralph Waldo Emerson
mods.accessCondition: For more information about rights and reproduction, visit http://specialcollections.vassar.edu/policies/permissionto.html
mods.note: The transcripts, originally made by Clara Barrus and Elizabeth Burroughs Kelley, should be viewed as a map to the original. Due to the difficulty of interpreting handwriting, complete accuracy of the transcripts cannot be ensured.

mods.accessCondition: For more information about rights and reproduction, visit http://specialcollections.vassar.edu/policies/permissionto.html
mods.note: The transcripts should be viewed as a map to the original. Due to the difficulty of interpreting handwriting, complete accuracy of the transcripts cannot be ensured.

mods.abstract: This journal includes Burroughs' usual musings on nature as well as notes on authors he was reading, particularly Thomas Carlyle and Ralph Waldo Emerson. There are also long passages about his father, who died in January 1884, accompanied by a brief family history.
mods.accessCondition: For more information about rights and reproduction, visit http://specialcollections.vassar.edu/policies/permissionto.html

mods.abstract: The time period covered in this journal was a fairly quiet period for Burroughs. He makes frequent reference to the death of his father, and later in the journal discusses faith and his thoughts on prayer and the Bible.
mods.accessCondition: For more information about rights and reproduction, visit http://specialcollections.vassar.edu/policies/permissionto.html
For more information about rights and reproduction, visit http://specialcollections.vassar.edu/policies/permissionto.html

mods.abstract: During the period covered in this journal, Burroughs published Fresh Fields (1885) and much of the journal relates to his writing and research. There is also a description of his visit with Walt Whitman in Philadelphia in December 1885.
mods.accessCondition: For more information about rights and reproduction, visit http://specialcollections.vassar.edu/policies/permissionto.html
mods.note: The transcripts, originally made by Clara Barrus and Elizabeth Burroughs Kelley, should be viewed as a map to the original. Due to the difficulty of interpreting handwriting, complete accuracy of the transcripts cannot be ensured.

mods.abstract: The period in Burrough' s life covered in this journal includes the death of his mother, the assassination of President Garfield, the passing of Ralph Waldo Emerson and the death of his favorite dog. He includes his usual reports on weather and nature, but also muses frequently on life and death.
mods.accessCondition: For more information about rights and reproduction, visit http://specialcollections.vassar.edu/policies/permissionto.html
mods.note: The transcripts, originally made by Clara Barrus and Elizabeth Burroughs Kelley, should be viewed as a map to the original. Due to the difficulty of interpreting handwriting, complete accuracy of the transcripts cannot be ensured.

mods.abstract: In this brief journal, Burroughs describes a summer visit with Walt Whitman. He also reminisces about his first experiences away from home.
mods.accessCondition: For more information about rights and reproduction, visit http://specialcollections.vassar.edu/policies/permissionto.html
mods.note: The transcripts, originally made by Clara Barrus and Elizabeth Burroughs Kelley, should be viewed as a map to the original. Due to the difficulty of interpreting handwriting, complete accuracy of the transcripts cannot be ensured.

mods.abstract: During the time period covered in this journal, Julian Burroughs was born (1878); Birds and Poets (1877) was published, as was Locusts and Wild Honey (1879). In addition to his regular comments on flora, fauna and weather, Burroughs also describes several visits with Walt Whitman and makes frequent mention of his concerns about his parent's health.
